content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will happen in about 45 minutes
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @_WG-rfc-2229 by nikomatsakis Matthew Jasper
  • @_wg-polymorphization by davidtwco
Also, experimenting a new more compact format for the backport nominations: feedback welcome!
Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! Its time for Thursday triage! Add a :wave: to show you’re here.

We’ll start off with five to ten minutes for

Announcements

• @rylev has written a document describing the current rustc performance evaluation process, and proposed changes to it, and they want feedback. THe doc is here: https://hackmd.io/@ryanlevick/Bk1Hidcbu
• and the associated zulip thread is in #t-compiler/performance > The short-term performance process review
^ To reiterate, this is the short term performance monitoring and triage process and is not meant to be a discussion of perf.rlo itself which should be examined separately.
Nor is it meant to be a discussion of the long-term performance monitoring process. This also deserves separate examination
• @Joshua Nelson points out: “Look at this graph!"
https://perf.rust-lang.org/bootstrap.html?start=2021-02-01&end=2021-02-21
congratulations to @cjgillot!
Notably a bunch of crates all became way less expensive to compile. This is due to @cjgillot ’s factoring of the query engine out of rustc_middle.
Really well done @cjgillot!
Is the proper way to read that graph that the entire rustc bootstrap compilation process takes roughly as long as the longest crate takes to compile? How parallelizable are the crates?

pnkfelix said:

https://perf.rust-lang.org/bootstrap.html?start=2021-02-01&end=2021-02-21

that's great :)

(You’ll note that rustc_middle had the biggest reduction in time, but you need to counter that against the new line that may be overlooked that shows rustc_query_impl … which I guess now takes the longest to compile ?)
@rylev I don’t think they’re all parallelizable. I’m certain there are dependencies.
That wuold be a cool thing to try to depict: What the critical path length is

pnkfelix said:

That wuold be a cool thing to try to depict: What the critical path length is

CARGOFLAGS_BOOTSTRAP=-Ztimings should show it
Well, I guess what I really meant was a directed graph of all the dependencies labelled with their compile times
or @Joshua Nelson are you saying that is readily derivable from -Ztimings ?
I’ll have to look into that I guess.
It only shows the graph traversal cargo happened to pick, but yes
I don't think the general graph is super useful without a way to make cargo compile dependencies in that order
I see. The thing I’m imaginging would let one attempt to predict what the new critical path would cost if you reduced the cost of an individual crate
Anyway!
here let me just post an example: https://jyn514.github.io/assets/cargo-timings-html5ever.html
Thanks @Joshua Nelson

MCPs/FCPs

  • New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.
  • Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Move query implementation outside rustc_middle" compiler-team#388
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "Never Rollup When Changing the compiler Directory" compiler-team#407
  • Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.
  • Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Add -Z unpretty flags for the AST and the THIR" compiler-team#408
    • "Eagerly construct bodies of THIR" compiler-team#409

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
  • Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Add NotSupported to std::io::ErrorKind" rust#78880
    • "impl PartialEq<Punct> for char; symmetry for #78636" rust#80595
    • "Demote x86_64-rumprun-netbsd target" rust#81514
    • "Make char and u8 methods const" rust#82078
/me wonders what Punct is
Punctuation I think
A token like :, ; or *.
ah, puncuation characters like + - or #. (and things like += are two of them)
WG checkins

• @_WG-rfc-2229 by @nikomatsakis @Matthew Jasper:
    • Discussed milestones for edition release: https://github.com/rust-lang/project-rfc-2229/milestones
    • disjoint_capture_drop_reorder lint partly implement to suppport migration around breaking changes across the edition boundry
    • T-Lang decided on migration syntax to be catpure!(var) within a closure to force a complete capture of var by the closure.
    • Implemented better support for precise captures in move closures

• @_wg-polymorphization by @davidtwco:

    There's no news from the polymorphization working group. Working group members have been focusing their efforts elsewhere in the compiler recently.

Backport nominations

T-compiler (stable)
T-compiler (beta)

• "Substitute erased lifetimes on bad placeholder type" rust#82494
    • opened by @Esteban Küber
    • not yet reviewed
    • Fixes rust#82455 a P-medium a stable to stable regression that emitted an ICE after showing a compilation error on invalid code.
/me whoahs at and
hmm okay hold on,. let me do this right
(now that I read it "B" and "S" next to each other are not that great :sweat_smile: )

• "Substitute erased lifetimes on bad placeholder type" rust#82494
    • opened by @Esteban Küber
    • not yet reviewed
    • Fixes rust#82455 a P-medium a stable to stable regression that emitted an ICE after showing a compilation error on invalid code.
Neat labels, hope it's not comentary on my pr's quality :grimacing:
sorry folks I've screwed up :D
(notably, I want to do the emoji-votes separately for vs
is :taxi: backport to stable?
omg
Seems fine for beta backport

• "Substitute erased lifetimes on bad placeholder type" rust#82494
    • opened by @Esteban Küber
    • not yet reviewed
    • Fixes rust#82455 a P-medium a stable to stable regression that emitted an ICE after showing a compilation error on invalid code.
So to be clear, in both the cases where you added this fix
we were already emiting a diagnostic before we ICE, right @Esteban Küber ?
Kind of, we ice when we fix a placeholder from another placeholder
Only the first one shows
But if you fix it you'll get the second one without ice
okay
Not critical
so a user can make progress on stable
its just not ideal
Yes
Okay. I personally think I’d decline to stable backport then
if anyone objects, feel free to privmsg me, or speak up at end of meeting
lets move on

T-libs-impl (stable)
T-libs-impl (beta)

  • No backport nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc (beta)
T-rustdoc (stable)

• "[intra-doc links] Don't check feature gates of items re-exported across crates" rust#82295
    • opened by @Joshua Nelson
    • approved by GuillaumeGomez Manish Goregaokar Camelid
    • fixes rust#82284, a P-critical regression that broke documentation for serde and other crates
note that it was only P-critical because libstd started using the feature gate
in 1.51, it wasn't active, so you'd have to add the feature gate in your own crate for it to matter
err, a crate you depend on
like we’ve stopped being able to run rustdoc on libstd?
libstd has always been able to be documented. The P-critical issue is that any crate without #![no_std] couldn't be documented
unless you add #![feature(intra_doc_pointers)]
We hit this in the nightly CI build for measureme last week

The P-critical issue is that any crate without #![no_std] couldn't be documented

and this was never true in 1.51, only in 1.52
the change itself seems low risk, and it sounds like its fixing something critical, so I guess I’m fine with a beta backport
I’m a little concerned about some of the feedback Manish wrote in the PR regarding the feature of intra-doc links in general
I don't think I'm explaining it very well :sweat_smile: but I agree it should be safe to backport

pnkfelix said:

I’m a little concerned about some of the feedback Manish wrote in the PR regarding the feature of intra-doc links in general

I wish they'd brought that up when I added it originally :/
yeah that happens. :)
anyway its not something we need to address nmow
and really, maybe its not our team’s job to figure that out anyway
i trust rustdoc team to resolve this question
beta backport approved

• "rustdoc: Remove duplicate "List of all items"" rust#82484
    • opened by @Dániel Buga
    • approved by GuillaumeGomez Manish Goregaokar Camelid
    • closes rust#82477, rustdoc showed a title twice in the header
^ This is super low risk but also low impact
it fixes a stable-to-beta regression
seems fine to me
beta backport approved.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

- "reduce threads spawned by ui-tests" rust#81942
- opened by @The 8472 (@The 8472?)
- @simulacrum raises concerns about maintaining the complexity cost, suggests more eyeballs on this PR
- @nagisa raise a concern that this could break tests sensible to the absence of a -Ccodegen-units flag
- CI seems to not pass consistently
I don't think this is necessarily in need of discussion
just wanted to bring some attention
I sort of am sad ci is so eager to fail on it, seems bad
Yeah I'm sure we have a plenty of tests that assume other defaults.
What’s up with the parts with -fuse-ld=lld ?
oh I see now
if we can infer that we’re using lld, then it tries to tell lld to limit its number of threads
Its too bad we don’t have a less … ad hoc way to figure things like that out
@simulacrum which is the main source of complexity that concern you here? The changes to runtest.rs itself?
ah
well, mostly that linkers are sufficiently different and the interface to reach them seems pretty platform specific iirc
yep
there’s definitely risk there
but it's mostly "do we want to maintain that? how many bug reports of 'your tests failed due to the fanciness you tried' will we get?"
I wonder how much benefit they would see if they left the linker changes out?
Okay well I think this serves the purpose of getting eyeballs on it
I think we can go ahead and land it, personally
of course the CI failures are concerning
and that may be a sign that we should not land it, if it makes existing flakiness in tests even more flaky
since that may hinder future work
but it also may just force us to address the flaky tests
so, yeah. I’m a little torn, but mostly in favor of trying to land it.
lets move along
it is a nice win

libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 64 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 38 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 1 P-critical, 39 P-high, 88 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "Starting with nightly-2021-01-13 (1.51) rustc fails to build archives on Windows 7" rust#81051
    • Assigned to @cuviper, comments this bug looks similar to LLVM #48378
    • Win7 (x86_64-pc-windows-gnu) is still Tier 1 platform: a side question about this issue could be if it should be demoted
    • the problem disappears if reverting to nightly-2021-01-12 or up to LLVM commit 6ec777c
we assigned task of reverting the cherry-picked commit to @cuviper last week
@cuviper do you think you’ll be able to follow through on that? Or should we reassign?
I'm happy to take a shot at reverting over the weekend if I find myself doing things around rustc.
(I suggest it should remain assigned to cuviper tho^^)
okay I’ll leave it assigned
(sorry, had to step away; wife was interviewed and wanted me to hit record on TV)

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

2021-02-24 full Triage Log

Overall, a positive week for compiler performance with only one moderate regression. The change that introduced the regression leads to significantly improved bootstrap speed of the compiler as well as easier maintainability.

Triage done by @rylev.

1 Regression, 5 Improvements, 0 Mixed
0 of them in rollups

Regressions

  • Move the query engine out of rustc_middle #70951
    • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 4.9% on full builds of deeply-nested-check)
    • While this does somewhat hurt compiler performance, it is a huge gain in bootstrap speed. The performance impact was deemed acceptable, but perhaps an investigation in if the remaining performance regressions can be eliminated, should be looked into.
    • Added a nag to the pull request.
(i’ll just note: its interesting to look at the other metrics on that perf link)
(other metrics besides instruction counts, that is)
(deeply-nested-check still registers 4.3% regression in wall-time. But its somewhat noisy.)

Improvements

  • Only store a LocalDefId in some HIR nodes #81611
  • Inline try_get_cached #82197
  • Reduce size of InterpErrorInfo to 8 bytes #82116
  • Make the Query enum a simple struct. #80891
  • Improve assert_eq! and assert_ne! #79100

Nags requiring follow up

  • One nag for the only regression for the week.
Hey @simulacrum and @rylev , aren’t there nags from previous weeks? Were those addressed, or are we not repeating them anymore in these reports?
hm I try to copy forward
it's easy to forget
its possible it was overlooked
They were addressed (at least the ones from last week)
awesome!
Its good to celebrate that in the report too, I think. Give people credit for following up or following through.

Nominated Issues

T-compiler
- "Invalid field is never read: lint warning" rust#81658
oh, nominated for T-lang I think.
skipping
- "reduce threads spawned by ui-tests" rust#81942
we disussed this

• "undefined reference to linker error when using dylibs" rust#82151
    - opened by @Alex Kornitzer, reports that working code on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu not compiling anymore after updating the MongoDB crate (compiled as dynamic library)
    - @Hameer Abbasi did some bisecting but the trail seems to go back to 2018
    - a minimal mcve is found at this comment
    - issue seems to warrant high priority but since it looks to be in the codebase since long, we are not sure about the implications/impact
mmm, yes, dylibs are not our forte
Okay so at this point it seems like we need to do a bit more dissecting
is it right to tag this as an ICE ?
/me cannot remember what precedent we have set for linker errors in the past
So, my thinking on this problem is: I’d personally rather focus on tasks related to next week’s shrinkmem sprint
it would be nice to figure out how big a problem this is
but can it wait until after the sprint?
not an ICE, /me fixes the labels
given how long the problem may have been present, it seems like it can wait a bit longer.
do we have a good way of delaying something for two weeks? :)
clearly need a @rustbot nominateme in 14 days
lets leave it nominated

pnkfelix said:

clearly need a @rustbot nominateme in 14 days

I'll write a post-it about it :)
P-high and ignore it for 2 triages?
worst case scenario, we talk about it next week for a minute
and that’s not really bad
yeah seems fine
P-high sounds good too, to me.

T-libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for T-libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
okay!
one minute left
Hey, we have a sprint next week!
How’s it going to work? I’m not sure
I haven’t followed through on my promise to deliver memory profiling docs. In part because I tricked myself into thinking I could figure out Mac OS X getrusage . Ha ha ha.
silly me.
Anyway
My thinking is that we’ll have topics in #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint
perhaps include a new daily topic each day
where people can just chime in with what they’re experimenting on related to the sprint
and at the end of each day, have a report of what’s happened
we’ll see. I’m trying to model it after some of the in-person sprints we’ve had in the past.
thats it for this week! Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!!!

rylev said:

Is the proper way to read that graph that the entire rustc bootstrap compilation process takes roughly as long as the longest crate takes to compile? How parallelizable are the crates?

By the way, @rylev , the -Ztimings info that @Joshua Nelson mentioned was applied to the bootstrap process back in January, and yielded the graphs shown here: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/70951#issuecomment-766292996
(so that gives one an idea on the effect this had on the critical path length.)
or … does it? I … am suprised that so few crates seem to depend on the completion of rustc_middle in that rendering on top ...
the blue vs purple must be meaningful there. I’ll look into it more.

pnkfelix said:

the blue vs purple must be meaningful there. I’ll look into it more.

ah okay; from cargo -Ztimings doc:

The "codegen" times are highlighted in a lavender color. In some cases, build pipelining allows units to start when their dependencies are performing code generation.

Draft for next week's agenda: https://hackmd.io/b3srlh3CR5aSTQPDi5I3tA?view

Scheduled checkins:

  • @WG-rls2.0 by @matklad
  • @WG-self-profile by @Wesley Wiser
